title: A Statue Gets Sprayed with Paint in London
summary: In London, a statue of Winston Churchill, a famous leader from long ago, was sprayed with red paint and words. The police arrested a 38-year-old man because they think he did it. The words on the statue said things like 'Stop the Genocide' and 'Free Palestine.' This happened in Parliament Square, a place with many statues. The statue has been cleaned up and blocked off so people can't touch it. This is not the first time this statue has been painted on; it happened before during protests. The police and city leaders are upset about the damage. The statue was made in 1973 and is very tall.

background_read: Winston Churchill was a British prime minister during World War II, known for leading the country. Statues are often put up to honor important people. Graffiti is illegal because it damages property. Protests can involve people expressing strong feelings, sometimes by painting on things. Parliament Square is a historic place in London with statues of leaders from around the world.
